title: Fernando Mendoza mock draft projection: Will Indiana QB go No. 1 overall in 2026 NFL Draft?
description: Fernando Mendoza has emerged as the top quarterback prospect for the first round after a Heisman-finalist season.
fullText:
Fernando Mendoza mock draft projection: Will Indiana QB go No. 1 overall in 2026 NFL Draft? originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

Fernando Mendoza wasn't expected to be the top quarterback prospect in the 2026 NFL Draft. Following his surprise Heisman Trophy-caliber 2025 season at Indiana, however, now he will be taken high in the first round as the first QB off the board on April 23.

Why has Mendoza shot up draft boards for his play, and what's his pro outlook?

Here's a profile of the Hoosiers passer, including what teams are most likely to draft him:

MORE:¬†The case for and against Fernando Mendoza for the Heisman

Mendoza (6-5, 225) has the ideal size as a strong pocket passer. The Cal transfer and Miami high school product was a hit in Curt Cignetti's dynamic offense. He's developed all the physical and mental qualities to be a top-10 pick for a QB-needy team.

Mendoza is very accurate with his short-to-intermediate passing. He is a good decision-maker who processes the field well. When he has a clean pocket, he can make all the throws. He also hangs tough in the pocket when facing pressure and is fearless in his execution. Mendoza is an aggressive thrower, but also avoids forcing the ball into coverage. He can zip it to take shots, but also adjust to show touch on passes when needed.

Mendoza can scramble for yardage when the defense breaks down and his big frame can help him on quarterback sneaks, but he won't add an element of plus athleticism to a team, as he's far less comfortable throwing on the run and won't provide any designed support for the running game. He will need to learn better how to dissect more complex pressure and coverage schemes in the NFL.

MORE:¬†College football bowl picks, predictions for CFP games

With the Giants (Jaxson Dart) and Titans (Cam Ward) taking first-round QBs in 2025, it's pretty clear where Mendoza might be headed. Here are the five teams to watch most to draft him

With Chip Kelly gone from the offense, Pete Carroll can look for a new OC with a pocket passer in mind to replace Geno Smith. It doesn't hurt that Mendoza's Big Ten clutch style would get a stamp of approval from part-owner Tom Brady.

The Browns will learn more about Shedeur Sanders for the rest of the 2025 season to see whether the rookie fifth-rounder deserves a more extended look to start in '26. If not, Cleveland would be firm play to try again at franchise QB.

MORE:¬†Where Fernando Mendoza projects in SN's latest mock draft

Will the Saints see enough from Tyler Shough to make a call either way on the second-round rookie QB? If they want to go higher into the draft pool for offensive-minded Kellen Moore, Mendoza has the Dak Prescott-like pocket qualities to execute his offense well.

Aaron Glenn and Tanner Engstrand saw the success of pocket-passing winning with Jared Goff (6-4, 217) in Detroit and may want to go that route to try again to strengthen the position for the long haul.

The Cardinals are heading to part ways with Kyler Murray and there might be some offensive coaching changes in store, too. Mendoza, Marvin Harrison Jr., Trey McBride and Michael Wilson would make for a good young passing game foundation.

title: Pitts' performance is most productive by NFL tight end since 1996, helps Falcons beat Bucs
description: Catch by catch, Kyle Pitts Sr. put the mistake-prone Atlanta Falcons on his back and carried them to a thrilling comeback victory over the Tampa Bay Buccaneers.  Thursday night got even better for the fifth-year pro when the former University of Florida star learned his 11-reception, 166-yard, three-touchdown performance that keyed a 29-28 win was the most productive game by an NFL tight end in nearly three decades.  The previous tight end to finish with at least 10 catches, 150 yards receiving and three TDs in a game was Hall of Famer Shannon Sharpe in 1996.
fullText:
TAMPA, Fla. (AP) ‚Äî Catch by catch, Kyle Pitts Sr. put the mistake-prone Atlanta Falcons on his back and carried them to a thrilling comeback victory over the Tampa Bay Buccaneers.

Thursday night got even better for the fifth-year pro when the former University of Florida star learned his 11-reception, 166-yard, three-touchdown performance that keyed a 29-28 win was the most productive game by an NFL tight end in nearly three decades.

The previous tight end to finish with at least 10 catches, 150 yards receiving and three TDs in a game was Hall of Famer Shannon Sharpe in 1996.

The 25-year-old Pitts noted he wasn't even born yet back then.

‚ÄúMan, I love the state of Florida,‚Äù the 6-foot-6, 250-pound Pitts said as he stepped up to the podium in the visiting interview room at Raymond James Stadium.

‚ÄúIt means a lot,‚Äù he added about the mention of Sharpe. ‚ÄúIt's a great person to be (compared to).‚Äù

Kurt Cousins targeted Pitts a team-high 12 times, leaning heavily on the young tight end with leading receiver Drake London out with a knee injury. Pitts scored on receptions of 8, 17 and 7 yards, the latter trimming what had once been a 14-point, fourth-quarter deficit to 28-26 with 3:34 remaining.

His last catch, on third-and-28 from the Atlanta 29, was for 14 yards. Cousins threw 21 yards to David Sills V on fourth-and-14 to set up Zane Gonzalez's 43-yard game-winning field goal as time expired.

‚ÄúIt was the plan, you know, all along. Kyle is our guy,‚Äù second-year Falcons coach Raheem Morris said. ‚ÄúYou're down a couple of your guys like Drake, some of those guys, and Kyle has really filled in that role and become the lead dog guy. He has done an awesome job.‚Äù

The Falcons (5-9) are eliminated from playoff contention, but they relished the opportunity to play spoiler against the division-rival Bucs (7-7), who are trying to win the NFC South for the fifth straight season.

‚ÄúIt's amazing. I mean, we've been having our ups and downs through the year,‚Äù Pitts said. ‚ÄúObviously, it's not fun being eliminated early, but we're resilient. ... It was just pretty fun to get that win.‚Äù

The Falcons overcame a team-record 19 penalties for 125 yards. They also withstood a wide-open Sills dropping what would have been a go-ahead TD catch in the third quarter, as well as Bijan Robinson's third-quarter fumble that led to the touchdown that put Tampa Bay up by two scores early in the fourth.

‚ÄúIt's a steppingstone to where we want to go,‚Äù Morris said. ‚ÄúWe talked about this, building blocks for what we've got to do. What we're talking about is next year. ... Only thing we can do right now is finish.‚Äù

AP NFL: https://apnews.com/hub/NFL

title: Can a nepo baby be an underdog? The remarkable rise of Shedeur Sanders
description: The quarterback was seen as living off his father‚Äôs name when he entered the NFL. But he has slowly started to prove himself at the Cleveland Browns
fullText:
It seems the goalposts are always moving on Shedeur Sanders, the Cleveland Browns‚Äô rookie quarterback who keeps throwing people off.

He excelled at two colleges to establish himself as a top NFL prospect, only to wind up getting picked in the fifth round of this year‚Äôs NFL draft in one of the most dramatic stock crashes in league history. He then distinguished himself in training camp, only to wind up as the back-up to the back-up. When Sanders was finally pressed into injury relief duty last month and led the Browns to just their third win of the season, the caveat was that his breakthrough had come at the expense of the even-worse Las Vegas Raiders. Last week against the struggling Tennessee Titans, Sanders became the first Browns quarterback to throw for more than 300 yards and three touchdowns and rush for another score in the same game since 1950. But for many, the bigger headline was that he lost. Again.

Earlier this week Sanders was named the Browns starter for the rest of the season, inviting even more scrutiny of a an already polarizing player. His supporters say Sanders is entitled to his shot; his critics say he lacks the skills to play in the NFL, question his attitude and paint him as a spoiled rich kid. Every argument seems to excavate deeper feelings about Deion Sanders, his Prime Time father who paved the way for his son‚Äôs success. In the age of the nepo baby, Shedeur makes for a strange underdog story.

There are expectations that come with being a starting quarterback in the NFL, after all. In addition to the requisite physical attributes and arm talent, the cliche dictates that quarterbacks are men of character ‚Äì players who speak in the first person plural, deflect credit, absorb blame and lead with modesty. It‚Äôs how the quarterback position became shorthand for a standard of American leadership that was largely reserved for conservative white men until recently. But Shedeur doesn‚Äôt even resemble the Black quarterbacks who have in the last few years broken from that tradition and transformed the league. Instead, in character at least, he resembles his father. Deion is a flashy, brash and supremely self-confident two-sport superstar universally recognized as one of the best players in NFL history.

After becoming the first Browns quarterback to win his first start since the team‚Äôs 1999 relaunch, a soundbite of Shedeur effectively congratulating himself for playing well despite his limited practice time overshadowed the more diplomatic remarks he‚Äôd make in praise of the team later. (‚ÄúImagine what a full offseason looks like,‚Äù he beamed. ‚ÄúIt gets dangerous!‚Äù) When he was asked last Sunday if a botched two-point conversion attempt had worked during practice, he laughed. (‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think you call plays in a game that didn‚Äôt work in practice,‚Äù he cracked.) After being criticized for his remarks in the media earlier this season, he was asked about the Browns‚Äô quarterback situation. Sanders repeatedly answered by grinning and then silently moving his mouth in response ‚Äì which had fans jokingly referring to him as Mime Time in a nod to his father.

‚ÄúWe want our quarterbacks to be very, very humble,‚Äù says Louis Moore, the Michigan State history professor and author of The Great Black Hope: Doug Williams, Vince Evans, and the Making of the Black Quarterback. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs not that. He‚Äôs grown up believing that he‚Äôs allowed to have confidence in himself. The world beats down a lot of young Black kids, and Deion never let it happen.‚Äù

The biased nature of the scrutiny on Shedeur, especially when things don‚Äôt go his way, often results in fans bringing up racism. They further wonder whether Browns head coach Kevin Stefanski holds a grudge against the Sanders family because his father-in-law, Tim McCarver, had an infamous run-in with Deion during the latter‚Äôs baseball career.

But the issue isn‚Äôt quite so black and white. Somehow, the Sanders family manage to inspire Obama-level respect and enthusiasm among Black Americans (who helped make Shedeur‚Äôs Browns jersey a bestseller) while also having Donald Trump in their corner. The current president hasn‚Äôt hesitated to cannonball into the Shedeur Sanders discourse, calling NFL owners ‚Äústupid‚Äù for letting him fall in the draft and trumpeting ‚ÄúI TOLD YOU SO!‚Äù on social media after Shedeur led the Browns past the Raiders. Trump couldn‚Äôt let those moments pass without making some mention of Shedeur‚Äôs ‚Äúexceptional genes‚Äù in what was otherwise a forceful show of support.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm just thankful for [Trump] even taking time out of his day to speak out,‚Äù said Shedeur, reveling in his nepo baby status. While Peyton Manning was determined to overshadow his father Archie‚Äôs fruitless years with the New Orleans Saints and Bronny James shrinks from the allusions to the more prominent Lakers player in his family, Shedeur has been happy to share a spotlight with his famous father for more than a decade.

A good chunk of his adolescence was documented on Deion‚Äôs Family Playbook, a reality TV series that ran on Oprah‚Äôs cable channel. Shedeur then played under his father when Deion coached at Mississippi‚Äôs Jackson State University and the University of Colorado, and the pair were instrumental in reviving both of those programs. Wherever Shedeur goes, there‚Äôs usually a camera following him ‚Äì and oftentimes his older brother Deion Sanders Jr, the architect of the family‚Äôs vast online media presence, is the one holding the camera. Around family, Shedeur reverts from a football star to a little brother who gets razzed about his fashion choices and his position on his father‚Äôs sibling power rankings.

Being Deion Sanders‚Äôs son made Shedeur savvy to how NFL storylines are shaped, and the one he‚Äôs crafted about himself strikes the media ‚Äì who are used to taking charge of the narrative ‚Äì as presumptuous. He calls himself ‚Äúlegendary‚Äù, shrugs off brickbats (‚ÄúYou think I‚Äôm worried about what critics say?‚Äù) and throws words like ‚Äúdestiny‚Äù around when projecting his career path. Resentments linger about his starry approach to the draft process that may well have cost him the chance to be picked higher. It was thought that Deion was the one quarterbacking things behind the scenes at this year‚Äôs draft, but he has since revealed that it was Shedeur who may have rebuffed higher draft opportunities in Philadelphia and Baltimore because he didn‚Äôt want to sit behind two established starters, Jalen Hurts and Lamar Jackson ‚Äì a pretty smart read as it turns out.

‚ÄúI know the fight behind the fight,‚Äù Deion Sanders said earlier this season. ‚ÄúI know what‚Äôs been transpiring behind the curtains, and I‚Äôm just proud of him. Because he‚Äôs not just saying the right things, he‚Äôs doing and living the right things. That‚Äôs just who he is ‚Ä¶ He‚Äôs a Sanders.‚Äù

Shedeur has only played in four NFL games, two of those against bad teams, which is too small a sample size to make concrete pronouncements about his career. But his performances so far for the Browns, a team who have sunk the careers of countless quarterbacks, hint that he is dramatically better than his lowly draft position suggests. And while his chance to finish out the season is the first true vote of confidence he has received since joining the organization, there‚Äôs a sense that he isn‚Äôt so much playing for his Browns future as he is playing for the chance to thrive elsewhere. That‚Äôs because the Browns made a $230m commitment to the injured Deshaun Watson and are determined to see if they can get their money‚Äôs worth when he returns to fitness. With this season long lost, really all that Shedeur has to play for is trade value, pride and teammate Myles Garrett shattering the single-season sack record ‚Äì but of course that‚Äôs the popular spin.

For Shedeur, it‚Äôs just the latest chapter in a story that ends with him going down as the one of the biggest underdog success stories in sports ‚Äì the draft afterthought who became an NFL legend. (Sound familiar?) That dissonance of an underdog with privilege shows the extent to which nepo babies have taken over the narrative.

title: Browns vs. Titans: 5 takeaways from Cleveland's NFL Week 14 loss
description: The Browns lost yet another one, and this time to the measly Titans. So, yeah, we have some thoughts.
fullText:
The Cleveland Browns' 31-29 loss to the Tennessee Titans in Week 14 was a study in frustrating contradictions.

On one hand, the team showed flashes of a potentially bright future, particularly on the offensive side of the ball. Rookie quarterback Shedeur Sanders delivered a statistical performance that should give the organization and its fans genuine hope for the future, leading the offense on a thrilling, if ultimately incomplete, fourth-quarter comeback attempt. His connection with fellow rookie Harold Fannin Jr. was explosive and dynamic.

On the other hand, the loss starkly illuminated the systemic flaws that have plagued the Browns throughout this disappointing season. The defense, usually a bedrock of strength, struggled significantly, particularly against the run game, allowing a career-day for Titans running back Tony Pollard. Furthermore, the persistent issues on the offensive line and costly mistakes, including a momentum-killing interception and two failed two-point conversions, proved to be the difference against a struggling Titans team.

This defeat, dropping the Browns to 3-10, was a painful reminder that potential, even when dazzling, is no substitute for consistency and flawless execution, especially when facing a team desperate for a win.

Here are five key takeaways from the snowy, frustrating afternoon at Huntington Bank Field.

Shedeur Sanders showed another significant step in his development on Sunday, logging the best statistical game by a rookie quarterback this year with 364 yards passing and three touchdowns, plus a rushing score.

23/42, 364 pass yds, 3 pass td, 29 rush yds, 1 rush td, 1 int

more highlights on https://t.co/xMzvHOeNay pic.twitter.com/mfCA7cgkGc

‚Äî Cleveland Browns (@Browns) December 8, 2025

Sanders showed up when the team called his number, orchestrating two late touchdown drives. However, the one play he definitely wants back is a costly third-quarter interception on what looked to be a scramble drill attempt, where he overshot his man, flipping the game's momentum.

Sanders is still holding onto the ball longer and more often than any other quarterback in the league, leading to unnecessary pressure, sacks, and backbreaking turnovers. But if his can be ironed out further and his internal clock can be sped up, the Browns might just have their future quarterback already at the helm, proving he can handle the NFL stage.

The rookie tight end out of Bowling Green, Harold Fannin Jr., continued his impressive run as a leading pass-catcher for the Browns.

Fannin racked up 114 yards and a touchdown on eight receptions against the Titans, marking a career-high for the young player and joining Ozzie Newsome as the only rookie tight ends in Browns history to record a 100-yard receiving game.

His blend of size, hands, and route-running ability makes him a matchup nightmare, and he is quickly solidifying his place as a core component of the Browns' offense for years to come. In an offense struggling for consistent playmakers, Fannin Jr.'s emergence is a major win.

Linebacker Devin Bush has been lights out for Jim Schwartz's defense this season.

Against the Titans, he added a key interception to his stat sheet, reading quarterback Cam Ward's eyes perfectly for a 44-yard return that set up a Browns scoring drive. Bush is playing like the dynamic, first-round pick the Steelers thought they were getting out of Michigan all those years ago.

Devin Bush intercepts Cam Ward!

TENvsCLE on FOX/FOX Onehttps://t.co/HkKw7uXVnt pic.twitter.com/adKxo8zSCL

In a league that values three-down linebackers, his strong, consistent performance this year, especially in coverage, has positioned him for a substantial contract in the upcoming free agency period.

The myth of the weather advantage was definitively debunked on Sunday. As the snow fell, the Titans' lead grew, largely due to the Browns' defense slipping and sliding all over the grass.

The conditions seemed to hamper Cleveland‚Äôs pursuit angles and tackling, leading to a career game from Titans running back Tony Pollard, who ran for 161 yards and two touchdowns.

Tony Pollard 65-yard TOUCHDOWN.

TENvsCLE on FOX/FOX Onehttps://t.co/HkKw7uXVnt pic.twitter.com/UZ9c5ifvfN

The Titans' effective ground-and-pound strategy mitigated the Browns' fearsome pass rush, turning the supposed home-field edge into a distinct disadvantage for the defense.

While Shedeur Sanders' tendency to hold onto the ball for a long time certainly allows for more pressure to be created, the offensive line is not without blame.

The unit's lack of consistency in play and availability has been a recurring and season-long problem, culminating in a performance where key starters suffered significant injuries. With starting center Ethan Pocic reportedly suffering a likely season-ending Achilles injury and other starters battling injuries, the unit is in shambles.

The team is likely looking to replace four of the five starters this offseason. A number that could be jumping to five of five if veteran left guard Joel Bitonio finally decides to hang up the cleats at season's end.

This article originally appeared on Browns Wire: Browns vs. Titans: 5 takeaways from Cleveland's NFL Week 14 loss

title: Week 15 NFL against-the-spread picks, predictions for every game: Patriots are 11-2 and underdogs this week
description: The Bills are two games behind New England but favored to win.
fullText:
The New England Patriots are tied for the best record in the NFL. And yet, they're not even favored at home this week.

An oddsmaker's power ranking doesn't always match public perception or a team's record. The Buffalo Bills are very unlikely to win the AFC East but they are still the favorites to win the AFC. The Bills have the shortest odds to win the conference at +375. That belief in the Bills is reflected in this week's point spread.

The Bills, who lost to the Patriots at home back in Week 5 and are two games behind New England in the standings, are 1-point favorites at BetMGM vs. the Patriots on Sunday. That's an interesting line.

The Patriots have been slighted a bit for playing the easiest schedule in the NFL so far this season, but winning 10 games in a row is difficult no matter the opposition. And the Patriots do have good road wins at Buffalo and at Tampa Bay. The Bills have Josh Allen, but they haven't been great. They have bad blowout losses to the Falcons and Dolphins. Last week they were in danger of losing to the Bengals at home until Christian Benford had a magical pick-6 and turned the game around. You can pick holes in New England's season if you wish, but the same can be done to the Bills. On top of it all, the Patriots are well rested coming off their bye week.

Maybe Josh Allen plays the superhero role and keeps the Bills' chances at an AFC East title alive (the Patriots clinch the division title with a win on Sunday) but we'll give some respect to the Patriots and make them the pick at +1. It seems like getting proper respect won't be easy for this Pats team.

Here are the rest of the picks for Week 15 in the NFL, with odds from BetMGM:

It's hard to back either team. The Bucs are coming off a miserable loss to the Saints, and their offense is in a slump. More specifically, Baker Mayfield is in a slump. His rating the last four games is 65.2. On the other side, the Falcons have lost seven of eight, and the last two gams were a loss to the lowly Jets and a 28-point loss to the Seahawks. But, we have to pick one of them.

The Bengals beat the Ravens 32-14 on Thanksgiving, in Baltimore. Not much has changed since. The Ravens are showing, week after week, they're not very good. So why are they favored here? Theoretically the Ravens could suddenly emerge as the stellar team everyone though they would be this season, but we've been waiting for that for months and it hasn't happened.

It seemed last week like the Commanders had one good performance left in them this season, and it came two weeks ago in a crushing overtime loss to the Broncos. Last week's effort against the Vikings was startlingly bad. They might already have their luggage packed for the trip to Cancun. The Giants aren't great either but they are rested after a bye.

There will be a few instances this week of teams in look-ahead spots. It's not all that common in the NFL, but how will the Bears get up to face the Browns when they know the Packers are coming to town six days later? The Browns have a good defense and until the past couple weeks, the theme of the Bears season was having a bunch of close wins, mostly over bad teams.

The only reason to believe in the Chiefs laying this many points is the argument that they are in must-win mode. But they've been in must-win mode for weeks. It hasn't mattered. The Chiefs aren't as bad as their 6-7 record (they're No. 6 in DVOA, haters) but this line seems a point or two too high. Would it be that surprising to see the Chargers win straight up?

The Eagles look broken and the Raiders are the NFL's worst team. What fun. Geno Smith is unlikely to start this week for the Raiders, which actually might not be a bad thing. Still, I can't take the Raiders. If there was ever a get-right spot for the Eagles, this is it. If they struggle here, they're really in trouble.

Brady Cook might get the start for the Jets because Justin Fields and Tyrod Taylor are hurt. Cook is an undrafted rookie who threw for 11 touchdowns in 12 games last season at Missouri. He'd be operating in an offense that hasn't been good no matter who is playing at quarterback. Anything seems possible in this weird NFL season, but this is a bad spot for the Jets.

The problem with taking the Cardinals is it's hard to figure out how they score on the NFL's best defense. But it's not like the Texans offense is a scoring bonanza either. Last week we took the Cardinals, based on the fact that a large number of their losses have been close. It didn't work out last week. Let's try again.

The Broncos certainly aren't without flaws, but a 2.5-point home underdog? That's surprising. Both 11-2 teams are underdogs at home this week, which says a lot about the wide-open nature of the NFL this season. Another factor in backing Denver: The Packers play at Chicago in Week 16 for what practically amounts to the NFC North title game. It shouldn't surprise anyone if they have an eye on that game.

This one is an even more extreme look-ahead spot. The Rams play at Seattle four days after this game in a meeting that could determine the NFC West and the No. 1 seed in the NFC. The Rams are a veteran team with a great coach, but how could they not be thinking a little bit about that game? Also, the Lions have extra rest after playing on Thursday night, which is usually an edge. Even if the Rams play well, the Lions have a good enough offense to always be in play for a backdoor cover. Be careful if you're taking the Rams here.

The Panthers have had a really weird season, with multiple quality wins and some miserable losses. One of those losses came to the Saints, and it wasn't all that close with New Orleans thoroughly outplaying Carolina in a 17-7 game. How could we know which Panthers team will show up? We'll hope for the one that is fighting for a division title late in the season.

The Titans have actually covered the spread in four of their last five games. It's not a good team but one that is still playing hard. The 49ers should blast the Titans. But that's not how the NFL typically works.

The Colts have eight wins and it wasn't just because of Daniel Jones. It has been a pretty good team this season, despite a recent slide. Yes, it's scary to depend on 44-year-old Philip Rivers or whoever plays quarterback against one of the NFL's best defenses. It could get ugly. But as is said often in this space, double-digit underdogs usually look hopeless, and then they somehow cover.

Proof that it would take a court order for the networks to flex a Cowboys game out of prime time. It's time to test whether Vikings quarterback J.J. McCarthy is turning a corner. He looked good last week, but that came against a really bad Commanders defense. If he can go on the road and have another positive outing against a Cowboys defense that has been better since the Quinnen Williams trade, maybe the narrative surrounding him will start to change. But let's see it happen first.

This is a strangely interesting game. The Dolphins started 1-6 but have rallied and aren't dead in the playoff race at 6-7. The Steelers can have some awful games, but they lead the AFC North at 7-6. It's a test for that Dolphins hot streak, considering they've been mostly beating bad teams and doing it with Tua Tagovailoa producing very little.

title: 2026 NFL draft: Where are the Jets' Round 1 picks after Week 14 loss?
description: Updating the New York Jets' first-round picks in the 2026 NFL draft following the Week 14 loss.
fullText:
The New York Jets were blown out in Week 14, losing 34-10 to the Miami Dolphins in Week 14.

Their record stands at 3-10 with four games remaining. The real-time 2026 NFL draft order is becoming clearer every week.

The Jets are slated to possess two first-round picks in 2026, their own and the one originally belonging to the Indianapolis Colts, as a result of the Sauce Gardner blockbuster trade. New York entered the weekend with their own selection at No. 7 overall and it did not change following Sunday's results.

Five 3-10 teams are currently scheduled to own picks 4-8, and head coach Aaron Glenn's squad has the second-best strength of schedule (.541) among that group.

The Jets stay at No. 7 in the draft order, per ‚Å¶@tankathon‚Å© pic.twitter.com/M3Sl1GqZk7

‚Äî Brian Costello (@BrianCoz) December 8, 2025

In better news, the pick originally belonging to the Colts was slated for 23rd overall entering Week 14. Following the Colts' blowout loss to the Jacksonville Jaguars, it has improved to No. 21. Starting quarterback Daniel Jones suffered a season-ending Achilles injury and Indianapolis fell to third place in the AFC South.

The Jets still don't own a top-five selection. If quarterbacks Tyrod Taylor and Justin Fields aren't able to return following their Week 14 injuries, it's difficult to imagine the Jets winning a game with rookie undrafted QB Brady Cook in the lineup. We'll be monitoring the updated draft order every week.

title: NFL to return to Munich in 2026 and 2028
description: The NFL will return to Munich to play regular-season games during the 2026 and 2028 seasons.
fullText:
The NFL will return to Munich to play regular-season games in both 2026 and 2028.

Germany has staged five games over the past four seasons, with Bayern Munich's Allianz Arena hosting in 2022 and 2024.

Berlin had its first game last month, and the NFL will also return to the German capital in 2027 and 2029.

Alexander Steinforth, general manager of NFL Germany, told BBC Sport "I think we'll have a good mix of two cities going forward", and the league has now confirmed a similar multi-year partnership with Munich.

In a statement on Wednesday, Steinforth added: "As the first host of regular season games in Germany, Munich holds a very special place in the hearts of our fans and we look forward to continuing to create memorable experiences for them, while building a year-round NFL presence across this city and country."

title: Colts sign grandfather Rivers, 44, out of retirement
description: Quarterback Philip Rivers has come out of retirement to rejoin the Indianapolis Colts, five years after the 44-year-old grandfather last played in the NFL.
fullText:
Philip Rivers has come out of retirement to rejoin the Indianapolis Colts, five years after the 44-year-old grandfather last played in the NFL.

The Colts faced a sudden need to fill their quarterback room after picking up two injuries during Sunday's 36-19 loss to the Jacksonville Jaguars.

Daniel Jones was ruled out with a season-ending Achilles injury and his replacement, third-string rookie Riley Leonard, picked up a knee problem.

Back-up quarterback Anthony Richardson was already out with a facial injury, so Rivers worked out for the Colts on Monday - his 44th birthday.

The father of 10, who has been serving as the head coach at St. Michael Catholic High School in Alabama, has now been added to the team's practice squad.

That makes Rivers the oldest current player in the NFL, surpassing Pittsburgh Steelers quarterback Aaron Rodgers, who turned 42 last week.

After spending the first 16 years of his NFL career with the Chargers franchise, Rivers joined the Colts in 2020 and led them to an 11-5 record, falling at the first hurdle in the play-offs.

The Colts, who were this season's pacesetters before losing their past three games to slip to 8-5, have promoted Brett Rypien from their practice squad to their active roster, making the 29-year-old eligible for Sunday's game at the Seattle Seahawks.

Rivers is seventh on the NFL's all-time list for passing yards (63,440) and sixth for touchdown passes (421).

Colts head coach Shane Steichen served as offensive coordinator and quarterbacks coach while Rivers was with the Chargers.

Rivers' eldest child is two months older than Colts rookie Leonard and leading up to this year's draft - when he was a sixth-round pick by Indianapolis - the 23-year-old worked with Rivers as the veteran lives in his hometown of Fairhope, Alabama.

Rivers' return could also affect his Hall of Fame status. Players become eligible five years after ending their career and, in his first year of eligibility, Rivers has been named a semi-finalist for the class of 2026.

If he remains on the Colts' practice squad, he will maintain his eligibility, but if he is elevated to the active roster, he will not be eligible again until the class of 2031.

title: NFL announces it will play regular season games in Munich, Germany in 2026 and 2028
description: Next season will mark the third time the NFL has played a game in Munich, Germany.
fullText:
The NFL is heading back to Munich. After playing games in the German city in both 2022 and 2024, the NFL announced Wednesday it will return to Munich in both 2026 and 2028 for regular-season games.

The move is part of a multiyear partnership with both the city of Munich and FC Bayern Munich. Games will be hosted at Allianz Arena, where FC Bayern Munich plays its home games.

The NFL today announced it will return to Munich, Germany in 2026 and 2028 to play regular season games, as part of a multi-year partnership with the City of Munich and FC Bayern Munich.

The games will be played at the FC Bayern Munich Stadium.

‚Äî Tom Pelissero (@TomPelissero) December 10, 2025

FC Bayern Munich confirmed the partnership, with the mayor of Munich, Verena Dietl, expressing excitement over "spreading the enthusiasm" for American football in the city.

"I‚Äôm delighted about the extension of our contract with the NFL and it once again shows the importance and strength of Munich as a sporting city. The previous games not only won the hearts of the fans, but also strengthened our successful cooperation with the NFL. Together, we‚Äôre committed to promoting American football in Germany and spreading the enthusiasm for the sport far beyond the stadiums. I'm looking forward to the upcoming games in 2026 and 2028, which will not only bring top-class sport, but also valuable impetus for grassroots sport in our city."

The NFL has played regular-season games in Munich two other times. The Seattle Seahawks and Tampa Bay Buccaneers played at Allianz Arena in 2022, with the Bucs coming out on top. Two years later, the Carolina Panthers beat the New York Giants in Munich.

Germany is no stranger to hosting NFL games at this point. In addition to those two contests, the Indianapolis Colts and Atlanta Falcons played a regular season game in Berlin, Germany earlier this year. The Colts won thanks to a tremendous performance from running back Jonathan Taylor.

The NFL has not announced which teams will take part in the Munich game in 2026 or 2028.

In recent years, the NFL has pushed to expand play outside the United States. The league has scheduled a number of international games each year, with six taking place during the 2025 NFL season. The NFL has played at least one game in the United Kingdom regularly since the 2007 season and has expanded international play to Brazil, Spain and Mexico, among other countries, in recent seasons.

The 2026 Munich game marks one of six international games announced by the NFL for next season. In addition to playing in Germany next year, the NFL will also play in Australia, Brazil and Mexico. The league will also play two games in the United Kingdom in 2026.

The league announced the Los Angeles Rams will play in the Australia game and that the Jacksonville Jaguars will appear in one of the games in the United Kingdom, but have not revealed any other teams taking part in international games next season.

title: NFL will play games in Munich in 2026, 2028
description: The NFL will be back in Munich during the 2026 season.
fullText:
The NFL will be back in Munich during the 2026 season.

The league announced that they will play a game at Allianz Arena, the home stadium of the soccer club FC Bayern Munich, next season. They will also play a game there in 2028.

Munich also hosted games in 2022 and 2024 while Frankfurt hosted two games in 2023 and Berlin made its debut as an NFL host city this season.

The league has also announced that it will play games in Melbourne, Australia and Rio de Janeiro, Brazil for the first time during the 2026 season. Two games are also set for Tottenham Hotspur Stadium in London and the league is expected to add more international games to the slate before the full schedule for next year is announced.

title: Jaguars jump up NFL power rankings entering Week 15
description: We‚Äôre back in the top 10 baybeee
fullText:
As Week 15 approaches, we rounded up the latest NFL power rankings to get a sense of how the Jaguars are viewed nationally.

Trevor Lawrence has taken major strides the past two weeks. It‚Äôs all starting to click in the new offense.

They played once at Levi‚Äôs Stadium this year. Could they be returning?

Most shocking statistical ranking: Wide receiver Brian Thomas Jr . is 50th in receiving yards

Expectations were pretty high for Thomas after a big rookie season ‚Äî 1,282 yards (third in the NFL) and 10 TDs ‚Äî but he has had issues catching the ball (five drops) and rookie Travis Hunter moved ahead of Thomas into the No. 1 receiver role by Week 7 before Hunter ‚Äòs season-ending injury. Thomas did miss three games because of an ankle injury and has had five catches for 115 yards in the two games since his return. But the team now views Jakobi Meyers ‚Äî whom they traded for on Nov. 4 ‚Äî as its No. 1 wideout. Thomas has 535 receiving yards so far.

They‚Äôre holding steady at No. 9 ‚àí and now firmly atop the AFC South with fifth-year QB Trevor Lawrence playing his most efficient football of the season heading into the stretch drive.

Nothing about Jacksonville‚Äôs successful season has felt intentional, let alone sustainable, but I think that the Jaguars are turning the corner. Quarterback Trevor Lawrence has finally found a good rhythm in the passing game, his receivers are catching the ball again, and the playoff picture is shaping up for the Jags to win a game or two this postseason.

After saying all that, I‚Äôm positive that this team will repay my belief by embarrassing itself in the next couple of weeks.

Beating the Colts was huge and probably wrapped up the AFC South for them. Still, it‚Äôs hard not to wonder how the game would‚Äôve played out if Indy hadn‚Äôt lost QB Daniel Jones.

If you were to ask me to identify Jacksonville‚Äôs superpower, I‚Äôd probably stumble my way through an answer before mentioning the run defense. But once Daniel Jones was knocked out of Sunday‚Äôs game, the Jaguars flexed their muscles and put the Colts away to wrest temporary control of the division. The Texans are coming, but these Jaguars are making things work in Liam Coen‚Äôs first season. He might be running third in the Coach of the Year race behind Mike Vrabel and Ben Johnson, but Coen‚Äôs offense looked nice early against Indy before slowing down after halftime. All in all, though, this team is playing good football at the right time. Jacksonville has allowed just 13 points per game over the past four, and it‚Äôs looking like the Jags could face undrafted rookie Brady Cook at QB when the Jets come to town this Sunday.

The Jaguars took control of the NFC South on Sunday, and there‚Äôs a good chance they secure their first division title since 2022 by winning three of their final four games.

With Daniel Jones injured for Indianapolis, the Denver Broncos are probably the only playoff-caliber challenge left on Jacksonville‚Äôs schedule. If the Jags don‚Äôt play down to the competition against the Colts, Jets and Titans, they‚Äôll host a playoff game.

How Jacksonville actually fares in the postseason will hinge on Trevor Lawrence‚Äôs play and the defense‚Äôs ability to force turnovers. The Jaguars haven‚Äôt won the turnover battle and lost a game since Week 2.

As wrong as I was about how Ben Johnson‚Äôs demeanor was going to translate to leading an NFL locker room, I may have been equally wrong about Liam Coen. Just look at the immaculate vibes taking place here.

Sunday changed everything in the AFC South. The Colts lost Daniel Jones, and the Jaguars picked up a critical win. It‚Äôs hard to watch the Jaguars and Texans and believe Jacksonville is the better team right now (more on the Texans in a bit) but they do lead the division. The AFC South might come down to whether the Jaguars can beat the Broncos or the Texans can beat the Chargers, because the other remaining games for both teams are all winnable.

From Josh Kendall and Chad Graff:

The Jaguars‚Äô first-year coach is in a neck-and-neck race with the Bears‚Äô Ben Johnson for the most performative postgame locker room speeches. After Jacksonville won for the fifth time in six games Sunday, Coen looked on the verge of breaking his players‚Äô hands high-fiving. He has the players believing, though. Josh Hines-Allen was even talking about the Super Bowl after recording his seventh sack.

The Jaguars‚Äô average rank this week is 9.6 (last week: 11.2).

The #Jaguars keep on climbing pic.twitter.com/mJqYwcOuw0

‚Äî Duval 22 (@duval22dotcom) December 10, 2025

Where would you rank the team, Jaguars fans? Let us know in the comments!

title: Arizona Cardinals sign WR Steven Sims to practice squad
description: Sims has had success as a kick returner in his NFL career.
fullText:
The Arizona Cardinals announced a practice squad addition and had a player from the practice squad depart. Cornerback Chigozie Anusiem, who had been on the practice squad since the start of the season, was signed by the Las Vegas Raiders to their active roster.

The Cardinals announced the signing of receiver Steven Sims, who had a tryout with the team on Monday.

Sims is 5-10 and 176 pounds. He has been in the NFL since 2019, playing for Washington, Pittsburgh, Houston and Baltimore. He has played in 53 games, starting six, and has 78 career receptions for 704 yards and five touchdowns. He also has averaged 25.2 yards on kick returns with a touchdown in his career.

It would not be a surprise to see him elevated this weekend to return kicks against the Houston Texans.

With Anusiem's departure, the Cardinals have 16 players on the practice squad. They have one vacancy. Here is the current makeup of the unit.

title: Lessons from a Record-Setting NFL Kicker on Performing Under Pressure
description: The career of National Football League kicker Brett Maher, one marked by both record-setting successes and public failures, offers useful insights for professionals facing high-pressure situations. In particular Maher employed three core practices: tuning out external criticism, focusing on process over outcomes, and embracing reflection and routine. Leaders under stress can use the same approaches to maintain composure, resilience, and continuous improvement when stakes are high.
fullText: Lessons from a Record-Setting NFL Kicker on Performing Under Pressure by Gretchen OltmanDecember 9, 2025PostPostShareSavePrintSummary.¬†¬†¬†Leer en espa√±olLer em portugu√™sPostPostShareSavePrintAt one point in his career Brett Maher, a National Football League (NFL) kicker who retired in 2024, boasted two records: most field goals made at 60 or more yards in single season (a mark recently surpassed) and most missed extra points in a single game. Over his decade as a professional athlete, he made 79.9% of the field goals he attempted and 95.5% of the extra points. And yet he was also released by 12 teams.

title: College football's best player is also a B-school grad and investing enthusiast with a stacked LinkedIn profile
description: Mendoza is a top prospect for the 2026 NFL draft, but if his football career doesn't pan out, he'd also probably be a top candidate for a job in finance.
fullText:
On Saturday, 22-year-old Fernando Mendoza led the Indiana Hoosiers to their first Big Ten championship since 1967 ‚Äî but the top quarterback's professional r√©sum√© looks nearly as impressive as his football record.

With their 13-10 win over Ohio State, Indiana secured the No. 1 seed in the College Football Playoff for the first time in program history ‚Äî and Mendoza's performance solidified his Heisman Trophy frontrunner status.

Born and raised in Miami, Mendoza was a two-star recruit out of high school and overlooked by most Power 4 programs. He was committed to playing at Yale until Cal lost a prospect and called him up with an offer he couldn't turn down: a free education and better football.

After three seasons at Cal, where he worked his way up to starting quarterback and graduated from the prestigious Haas School of Business, he transferred to Indiana last winter. The move meant losing his scholarship with Cal, but earning a lot more money in endorsement deals.

According to the Wall Street Journal, one of the first things he did with his "name, image, likeness" earnings was to cover the cost of the two classes he needed to graduate from Cal after his scholarship was terminated.

Mendoza, who's now pursuing his master's at Indiana's Kelley School of Business, spends more time on LinkedIn than he does on Instagram, TikTok, or other social platforms.

"The only social media that's on my phone right now is LinkedIn and YouTube to watch videos," he told The Herald Times. He has an Instagram account with more than 80,000 followers, but enlists his younger brother, Alberto, who also plays quarterback for the Hoosiers, to manage it.

A post shared by HeraldTimesOnline (@heraldtimesonline)

Mendoza is a top prospect for the 2026 NFL draft, but if his football career doesn't pan out, he'd also be a top candidate for a job in finance.

He's spent his last few summers interning at real estate investment firms ACRE and Newmark. Juggling his internships with hours of football practice required a 5:30 a.m. wake-up call and an intricate whiteboard, where he'd keep a running list of action items.

Mendoza is just as disciplined with his money as he is with his schedule.

"He doesn't spend any money on himself," his mom told the WSJ. "All he does is invest."

A post shared by Big Ten Network (@bigtennetwork)

His brother, with whom he shared a room growing up and now shares a car, pointed out that he also doesn't like to spend money on gas.

Alberto told Big Ten Network: "I go to use the car, and it's empty. There's no more gas in the car, and I'm like, 'We're just gonna use the car and not fill it back up?' And Fernando is like, 'Oh, yeah, sorry, my bad.' ‚Ä¶ And then I have to go to the gas station on like one mile of gas."

title: Rodgers keeps hopes alive but end of the line for Chiefs? Best of NFL week 14
description: Our pick of week 14 in the NFL as Aaron Rodgers salvages his season but it could be game over for the Kansas City Chiefs, while Josh Allen again shines for Buffalo.
fullText:
Every game counts from here on in, with some huge results in week 14 of the NFL that could settle play-off spots come the end of the season.

A 42-year-old Aaron Rodgers struck a big blow to Lamar Jackson's play-off hopes, while Josh Allen all-but ended Joe Burrow's.

Houston's defence is the biggest problem in the NFL and they may have ended the Kansas City Chiefs' season earlier than ever before with Patrick Mahomes as quarterback, while the Packers and Bears played out one of the best games in their long rivalry.

Here's what else caught the eye in week 14.
